teal.render.j3d

Class ViewerJ3D

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • javax.swing.JComponent
          • javax.swing.JPanel
            • teal.ui.UIPanel
              • teal.render.viewer.Viewer
                • teal.render.viewer.AbstractViewer3D
                  • teal.render.j3d.ViewerJ3D
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.beans.PropertyChangeListener, java.io.Serializable, java.util.EventListener, javax.accessibility.Accessible, HasID, TElement, THasPropertyChange, HasBoundingArea, HasCanvas, HasPickCanvas, HasUniverse, TViewer, TViewer3D

    public class ViewerJ3D
extends AbstractViewer3D
    A Java3D implementation of the AbstractViewer3D/TViewer interface. Manages all aspects of the Java3D scenegraph, including the Canvas3D on which it is displayed.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • ViewerJ3D

        public ViewerJ3D(boolean useDefaultScene,
                 boolean tryStereo)
        Constructs a ViewerJ3D.
        Parameters:
        useDefaultScene - determines whether or not the viewer should use the default lighting arrangement.
        tryStereo - determines whether the viewer should be configured for stereoscopic rendering (this should almost always be false).

        public void setFogTransformFrontScale(double percent)
        sets fogTransformFrontScale. This is used in setFogTransform(). fogTransformFrontScale multiplies the distance of the camera from the origin when setting fog via setFogTransform().

      • isFogEnabled

        Description copied from interface: TViewer3D

      • setFogTransform

        public void setFogTransform(javax.media.j3d.Transform3D trans)
        This is the method called by the FogBehavior that adjusts the parameters of the fog node as the camera transform changes. Currently, it is designed to maintain an aesthetically pleasing "depth of field" effect, regardless of the degree to which the camera is "zoomed". In other words, it strives to keep objects at the origin suitable "fogged", such that their front side is perfectly visible and their back side is moderately obscured by the fog. If these adjustments were not made, the amount of fog obscuring an object would be proportional to the distance between the camera and object. If you zoomed all the way out, objects at a given distance would become completely obscured by fog.
        Specified by:
        setFogTransform in interface TViewer3D
        Specified by:
        setFogTransform in class AbstractViewer3D
        Parameters:
        trans - this typically represents the viewport transform supplied by the FogBehavior.

      • getSaveFrame

        public boolean getSaveFrame()

      • saveScreenImage

        public void saveScreenImage()
        This method doesn't work at the moment. In principle, it should capture an image of the viewer and save it to disk. I suspect it is broken because it requires the viewer to be running in the OffScreen rendering mode, which it isn't. I can't find any proof of this requirement in any Java3D documentation, though.
